awd_titl_txt: RUI: Low Energy Electron Scattering from Fundamental Molecular and Atomic Targets
awd_abstract_narration:
The project involves experiments to study how low energy electrons collide with atomic or molecular gases, undertaken in collaboration with theoretical physicists. The studies will help elucidate the basic physics of collisions as well as have applications in ozone chemistry, combustion, the microelectronics industry, and astrophysics (from observations of light emitted in electron collisions with atoms and molecules in space). The project heavily involves undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups in a region of the country which has predominantly Hispanic and other minority students. The students are mentored to learn hands-on broad experimental science laboratory skills and go on to further education towards a Masters or PhD. In the past 26 years, the project has involved about 120 undergraduate students. In 2005, the PI was given a prestigious National Award for Outstanding Research in an Undergraduate Institution "For his challenging and sophisticated experiments in electron-atom collisions that have provided significant tests of atomic theory and for his energetic, sustained mentoring of students in his research."

The focus of the project is to obtain scattering cross sections for electron scattering from fundamental atomic and molecular gaseous targets, for elastic electron scattering and for excitation and ionization of these targets at very low energies (around 1eV to 100eV), including energies well above the ionization energy of these targets. Recently, to complement their differential-angle, high-resolution, low energy electrostatic electron spectrometer, the laboratory (PI and undergraduate students) designed and built a differential-angle time-of flight electron spectrometer, which is uniquely suited to study very low energy electron collisions. This is presently the only system existing world-wide. In 2018-2019 it provided benchmark collision data for molecular hydrogen to test the theoretical work from Curtin University and Los Alamos National Laboratory. The two lab spectrometers continue to be deployed to study other fundamental targets such as carbon monoxide and water. The PI collaborates with leading groups in theoretical modeling of electron scattering, e.g. at Los Alamos National Laboratory in USA, Drake University in Iowa USA, Curtin University in Australia, Charles University in Prague, University College in London UK, and several theory and experimental groups in Brazil, Canada and India.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Merit Review Facts.

The PI is retired from his position since December 31 2023 as faculty at his institution  (California State Unversity, Fullerton, CSUF). So this review addresses the contiguous support from NSF since 1992 to the present, but focused mostly on the present.

(1) Intellectual Merit: Since its build-up from the ground-up in 1991 from the PI's start at CSUF (an Undergraduate Institution) the project involved experimental low energy electron scattering from gaseous targets, comprising fundamentally of atoms, diatomic molecules an polyatomic molecules. The PI has performed (mainly) useful measurements of angle-differential scattering rates (or better known as differential cross sections, DCS) for elastic and inelastic scattering a range of atomic targets such as the rare gases helium, neon, argon, krypton and xenon and atomic hydrogen. He has extended these for diatomics molecular hydrogen, molecular nitrogen and carbon monoxide. He has extended these for many polyatomic targets such as water, the simple alcohols, alkynes, alkenes, benzene-type compounds. Since the results have spaned a large range of incident electron energies (≈ 1 eV to 100 eV), the results been used to test the computational accuracy of quantum-mechanical models for such electron scattering systems from frontline line groups worldwide. The measurements have included polarization correlation parameters and sensitive DCS ratios to further elucidate the physics involved in such scattering systems as opposed to the basic engineering of it. Thus in some cases he has directly been able to question the basic framework (wavefunctions, scattering potentials, etc.) of these models. Most of the work has been published in premier peer-reviewed journals. The PI has been able to solicit collaboration from world-wide groups (USA, UK, Canada, India, Brazil, Europe, Australia) consistently in his work since the start of his funding. In the last 29 years, the primary source of funding has been NSF. He has published letters, contributed articles and regular articles some of which have received highlights merits in these journals. His work has been varied over a range of topics to provided data for theoretical model as well as (industrial and environmental) applications. And he has done this successfully in an undergraduate institution building experiments from the  ground and up. He has presently left three instruments (spectrometers) in the lab at CSUF which will be used by faculty that will take over the lab. 

(2) Broader Impacts: The project has involved well over 150 undergraduate students and six postdocs who have benefited from this experience by focusing to higher levels and participating in building prototype instruments, data aquisition and analysis, electronics, wiring and maintenance of the vacuum chambers and equipment. The students (mostly from familes that have not send children to university) have gone to better industrial jobs, or to do PhDs in physics/chemistry/engineering. The lab has attracted students as a recruitment tool and has benefited the university. The project has developed an electron scattering lab that is working at his instituition at CSUF and will provide useful expertimental data on low energy electron collisions. It has become a recruitment tool for the University. Among several awards the PI has received is  a national award:  Research Corporation & American Physical Society, Outstanding Research in an Undergraduate Institution (2005): Citation: For his challenging and sophisticated experiments in electron-atom collisions that have provided significant tests of atomic theory and for his energetic, sustained mentoring of students in his research.? This has set an example for the faculty at his Institution.

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2023
Modified by: Murtadha A Khakoo
